Ben Franklin, one of our most influential Founding Fathers, wrote that we have ‘a Republic, if you can keep it.’ I believe we must fight to keep it. (END)
But, in the interest of defending our nation, I was compelled to vote to ensure our country holds the same values for our children and for generations to come.
Unchecked, these actions could lead us down a path that will unravel the fabric of our nation. I am saddened to have had to vote in favor of these articles of impeachment.
And it was an unacceptable obstruction of Congress for the President to order his officials to defy legally-issued subpoenas.

It was a severe abuse of power for the President to ask a foreign nation to interfere in our election to benefit his personal and political interest and to condition bipartisan and Congressionally-approved aid on that interference.
Every elected official must dedicate themselves to protecting our democracy. No one should invite a foreign country to interfere with our most sacred act of voting.
As a combat veteran and having served eight years on the Intelligence Committee, I understand the threat that foreign actors can play in our elections.
The two articles I voted to pass today outline serious breaches of the public trust committed by the President, rising to the bar of high crimes and misdemeanors spelled out in our Constitution.
Unfortunately, the President brought this on himself by putting his own personal and political interests above those of the people he serves. This jeopardized our national security.

THREAD on my vote today to approve articles of impeachment: This is a solemn duty outlined in the Constitution and one that I do not take lightly. I did not run for Congress to impeach this President, but rather to help our community get ahead and to serve the country I love.

Third: the opening offer from the Administration made it harder to lower prices on prescription drugs, a provision we were able to remove so we can lower costs on medications. This is a win for our nation and I was proud to be part of the negotiating team.
Second: the initial agreement also had weak labor enforcement and our talks yielded a strong enforcement mechanism to help protect our workers.

First: the initial agreement had weak labor monitoring provisions and our negotiations secured labor attaches in Mexico to report back on local labor practices and established benchmarks for Mexico’s labor reform process.
